fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In , we endow \operatorname {H}^\bullet (Y_\bullet ) with a mixed Hodge structure. Let \operatorname {\mathscr {H}}(\alpha ) be the mixed Hodge structure on \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X) induced by .

With the above notation, the mixed Hodge structure \operatorname {\mathscr {H}}(\alpha ) on \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X) is independent of the choice of \alpha . We call it the mixed Hodge structure of \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X,\mathbb {Z}). For every morphism f\colon X_1\to X_2 of schemes, f^*\colon \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X_2)\to \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X_1) is a morphism of mixed Hodge structures.
The proof uses , and is parallel to that of (C) of (cf. also [hodge-theory-iii-8.3.3 (?)]).
For smooth X, we can show, by taking \overline {Y}_\bullet to be a constant simplicial scheme, that the mixed Hodge structure in coincides with that defined in .

The pairs (p,q) such that the Hodge number h^{pq} of \operatorname {H}^n(X) are non-zero satisfy the following conditions:
(p,q)\in [0,n]\times [0,n].
If \dim X=N, and n\geqslant N, then (p,q)\in [n-N,N]\times [n-N,N].
If X is proper, then p+q\leqslant n.
If X is smooth, then p+q\geqslant n. The same conclusion holds if X is an equidimensional "rational homology manifold" of dimension N, i.e. if, for all x\in X, \operatorname {H}^i_{(x)}(X,\mathbb {Q}) = \begin {cases} 0 &\text {if }i\neq 2N \\\mathbb {Q} &\text {if }i=2N. \end {cases}

Claim (ii) will be proven in [hodge-theory-iii-8.3.10 (?)]. Claim (i) follows from (iii) of . For proper X, we can find a diagram as in in which Y_\bullet =\overline {Y}_\bullet , and (iii) then follows from (iv) of . For smooth X, (iv) follows from and . The general case then follows: if p\colon \widetilde {X}\to X is a resolution of singularities of X, then p^*\colon \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X,\mathbb {Q})\to \operatorname {H}^\bullet (\widetilde {X},\mathbb {Q}) is injective, since the Poincaré dual transpose p_! of p^*\colon \operatorname {H}^\bullet _\mathrm {c}(X,\mathbb {Q})\to \operatorname {H}^\bullet _\mathrm {c}(\widetilde {X},\mathbb {Q}) is a retraction for it.

Let Y \xrightarrow {f} X \overset {j}{\hookrightarrow } \overline {X} be morphisms of schemes. Suppose that Y is proper and X is smooth, and that \overline {X} is a smooth compactification of X. Then \operatorname {H}^\bullet (\widetilde {X},\mathbb {Q}) and \operatorname {H}^\bullet (X,\mathbb {Q}) have the same image in \operatorname {H}^\bullet (Y,\mathbb {Q}).

The proof is parallel to that of . It suffices to prove, for any i and any n, that \operatorname {Gr}_i^W(f^*) and \operatorname {Gr}_i^W((jf)^*) have the same image in \operatorname {Gr}_i^W\operatorname {H}^n(Y,\mathbb {Q}).
For i>n, these images are both zero since \operatorname {Gr}_i^W\operatorname {H}^n(Y,\mathbb {Q})=0 ((iii) of ).
For i<n, these images are both zero since \operatorname {Gr}_i^W\operatorname {H}^n(X,\mathbb {Q})=0 ((iv) of ).
For i=n, these images are equal since \operatorname {Gr}_n^W(j^*) is surjective ().

Let \widetilde {X} \xrightarrow {\pi } X \xrightarrow {f} Y be morphisms of schemes. Suppose that Y is smooth, X is proper, \widetilde {X} is smooth and proper, and that \pi is surjective. Then the kernels of f^* and (f\pi )^* in \operatorname {H}^\bullet (Y,\mathbb {Q}) are equal.

We will prove that \operatorname {Ker}(\operatorname {Gr}_i^W(f^*))=\operatorname {Ker}(\operatorname {Gr}_i^W((f\pi )^*)) in \operatorname {Gr}_i^W\operatorname {H}^n(Y,\mathbb {Q}).
For i<n, these kernels are both zero since \operatorname {Gr}_i^W\operatorname {H}^n(Y,\mathbb {Q})=0 ((iv) of ).
For i>n, these kernels are both all of \operatorname {Gr}_i^W\operatorname {H}^n(Y,\mathbb {Q}) since \operatorname {Gr}_i^W\operatorname {H}^n(X,\mathbb {Q})=0 ((iii) of ).
For i=n, these kernels are equal since \operatorname {Gr}_n^W(\pi ^*) is injective ().

Let X be a topological space. Then a cohomological Hodge A-complex K of weight n on X consists of:
a complex K_A\in \operatorname {Ob}\mathrm {D}^+(X,A),

The following statement reformulates a part of classical Hodge theory (cf. ).

Let X be a complex Kähler variety. Let K_\mathbb {Z} be the complex \mathbb {Z}[0] consisting of the constant sheaf \mathbb {Z} in degree 0, and let K_\mathbb {C} be the holomorphic de Rham complex \Omega _X^\bullet , with F its stupid filtration. We have \alpha \colon K_\mathbb {Z}\otimes \mathbb {C}\simeq \mathbb {C}[0]\xrightarrow {\approx }\Omega _X^\bullet (the Poincaré lemma), and (K_\mathbb {Z},(K_\mathbb {C},F),\alpha ) is a cohomological Hodge complex of weight 0.
If K is a Hodge complex (resp. cohomological Hodge complex) of weight n, then K[m] is a Hodge complex (resp. cohomological Hodge complex) of weight n+m.
